body: god
LGTM
There is a question, will it cause relatively large performance overhead or network bandwidth problems for business applications? Or we need to define the level of collecting logs on the agent?

@zifeihan @EvanLjp Could you take a look at existing log collection plugin, recently added.
We should enhance it rather than building a new one. Speaking about the channel, I prefer separate channel is an optional feature for the plugin. Because not all people are going to use satellite.

> There is a question, will it cause relatively large performance overhead or network bandwidth problems for business applications? Or we need to define the level of collecting logs on the agent?

1. The extension plugins is an appender plugin for log framework, such as Logback. The collected logs could be controlled by logback.xml by loggers or level. So the agent should not care about which logs should be collected. 
2. For the performance, In the future Satellite will support file reading, but for cloud disk mount, there will still be network consumption, so the first version prefers to use localhost network transfer to deliver the log data. I have no relevant experience in network performance testing, which I will learn about in the near future.

> @zifeihan @EvanLjp Could you take a look at existing log collection plugin, recently added.
> We should enhance it rather than building a new one. Speaking about the channel, I prefer separate channel is an optional feature for the plugin. Because not all people are going to use satellite.

Okay, let me take a look first.

> > There is a question, will it cause relatively large performance overhead or network bandwidth problems for business applications? Or we need to define the level of collecting logs on the agent?
> 
> 1. The extension plugins is an appender plugin for log framework, such as Logback. The collected logs could be controlled by logback.xml by loggers or level. So the agent should not care about which logs should be collected.
> 2. For the performance, In the future Satellite will support file reading, but for cloud disk mount, there will still be network consumption, so the first version prefers to use localhost network transfer to deliver the log data. I have no relevant experience in network performance testing, which I will learn about in the near future.

I am worried that the log is too large and frequent. We can configure another level in the agent. For example, if it is not configured, it will be consistent with logback.xml. If it is configured, we can filter it once. Perhaps this level can be dynamically adjusted.

> I am worried that the log is too large and frequent. We can configure another level in the agent. For example, if it is not configured, it will be consistent with logback.xml. If it is configured, we can filter it once. Perhaps this level can be dynamically adjusted.

Take a look, it is already there. That is why I am asking for enhancing the existing plugin rather than writing a new one.

> > I am worried that the log is too large and frequent. We can configure another level in the agent. For example, if it is not configured, it will be consistent with logback.xml. If it is configured, we can filter it once. Perhaps this level can be dynamically adjusted.
> 
> Take a look, it is already there. That is why I am asking for enhancing the existing plugin rather than writing a new one.

Get it, Log-plugin has made certain filtering rules, we can enhance it.
What do you do? We don't know this bug, or related things. CI, e2e tests, and local tests passed.
What do you analyze? Do you want to save the headers in the trace or something?
@wu-sheng @sj1231984  I also encountered a similar problem in v8.3.0. When I introduce apm-spring-annotation-plugin-8.3.0.jar, using jpa's findById will throw an exception
@zifeihan Do you have slot to take care of this?

> @zifeihan Do you have slot to take care of this?

Ok, I will try to reproduce and fix.

For example, with some user information in the header, Skywalking intercepts requests and custom extensions to save user information, which can then be analyzed to specify the user's call chain.Something like that. Thanks
Take a look at `plugin.http.include_http_headers` in https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/v8.3.0/docs/en/setup/service-agent/java-agent/README.md#table-of-agent-configuration-properties
@a6205206z Do you solved it?
same error

In previous implementation, I swap the buffer every time write operation has finished. If two write operations happen continuously, read-buffer will be not empty at second write operation.
1. At beginning:
read-buf[], write-buf[]
2. first write method finished, swap:
read-buf[data1], write-buf[]
3. second write method finished, swap:
read-buf[data2], write-buf[data1]
4. read:
read data2. out of order.

@qianglu1989 
its a bug when u use elasticsearch as storage.

how to solve:

Yes, reading operation always obtain all data in read-buf. But the frequency of reading is slower than writing. When writing operation happen continuously,  in the first round, read-buf is empty,  swapped. But in the second round, the read-buf has not been read yet, now the read-buf is not empty. The writer thread shouldn't swap the buffer.
By following this path, it looks like we could make switch happens driven by `read` rather than `write`? It could reduce the complexity of the logic.
Invalid issue.
Thanks a lot! I complicated the logic. Swapping the buffer after reading finished is much better, which no need to check whether read-buffer is empty.
Would you submit the pull request to improve the master branch?

Thanks. And there is another problem I didn't notice before. The reader can only obtain the data in read-buf currently, not all of data, which may produce delay.  In the worst situation, if writer thread write `data1` right after the first round reading finished, then `data1`  can only be read until the third round reading, which delays for 2*(reading period). Is this acceptable?

> if writer thread write data1 right after the first round reading finished

First, every write should be in the `write buffer`, correct? Then once the switch happens, it will be read. You set the lock for the switch before the read and write. There should be no chance the data could write into the `read buffer` in any case.

Oh, I complicated it again. Is that swapping happens before the `readBufferPointer.read()` call? Then there is no delay like that. I made a mistake that I thought swapping is called right after `readBufferPointer.read()`.

No matter how you put the codes, the key is, reduce the duration of locking, and only lock when you need to switch.

Base on the discussion, you will find, the key to improve the codes(from my understanding), is to move `readBufferPointer.read()` out of lock. Others don't impact the performance much, what do you think?

Went through the issue and it seems that when we use a static httpclient the connections are reused from the pool. 

So the instrumentation code never goes beyond `line no 439` as it finds a free connection from the pool and reuses it. [Code for checking free connections](https://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-core-ga/httpcore-nio/xref/org/apache/http/nio/pool/AbstractNIOConnPool.html#L439)

The instrumentation code relies on a new `SessionRequestImpl` instance creation being intercepted from `SessionRequestConstructorInterceptor` which is never reached in case of static httpclient and the trace breaks.
[Making a new connection](https://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-core-ga/httpcore-nio/xref/org/apache/http/nio/pool/AbstractNIOConnPool.html#L481)

What would be a good way to fix this because as per my understanding the assumption that a new `SessionRequestImpl` will be created for every request is erroneous and making httpclient static is actually the right way to use it.

Hi, I am not very familiar with the codes of this part, so the following answer would be based on your description only.
____
The key usage of `SessionRequestConstructorInterceptor` is for propagating the tracing context into the async thread through `#setSkyWalkingDynamicField`. When(no matter what is the right way to use httpclient) you do from a connection pool, the execution should be also in another thread(right?). You need to find a place the thread-switch happens, and update `SessionRequestImpl`. `SessionRequestImpl` should only be used in one thread at once, right?

I did try to do this, but I found that if you call the close method directly, the connection cannot be closed. The phenomenon is that the number of threads will be reduced by 10 after the connection is closed, but it will be created back, which does not solve the problem. The specific reason I suspect is to use HttpAsyncCloseableHttpAsyncClientBase will judge the link status when closing the link, causing the closing to fail. I haven't found any further reasons~
